keyTakeAways: Two top Chinese military leaders, He Weidong and Miao Hua, have been expelled from the Communist Party and the People’s Liberation Army over corruption charges, marking the most senior military purges since the Cultural Revolution.

He Weidong, the second-highest-ranking general and former vice-chair of the Central Military Commission, is also a member of the Politburo, making this action significant beyond the military into China’s political core.
The expulsions are part of President Xi Jinping’s broader anti-corruption drive, with analysts interpreting it as a consolidation of power within the military and political leadership.

He Weidong had strong ties to President Xi Jinping, including service in Fujian and Zhejiang provinces in the 1990s, and was involved in key military operations such as live-fire drills around Taiwan in response to U.S. political actions.
The removal of He and Miao occurs just before the Central Committee's Fourth Plenum, suggesting a planned leadership transition and potential reshaping of the Central Military Commission.

Multiple senior officials, including former political commissars and joint operations commanders, were named in the purge, indicating a wide-scale campaign targeting high-ranking personnel with ties to the military's political structure.
Former People’s Armed Police commander Wang Chunning was also removed from the national legislature, indicating the campaign extends beyond the military into broader national governance bodies.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Two top Chinese military leaders, He Weidong and Miao Hua, have been expelled from the Communist Party and the People’s Liberation Army over corruption charges, marking the most senior military purges in decades. He Weidong, a former vice-chair of the Central Military Commission and Politburo member, is particularly significant due to his close ties with President Xi Jinping and his role in high-stakes military operations around Taiwan. The purges are part of a broader anti-corruption campaign initiated in 2023, aimed at restructuring military and political leadership. The removals occur just before the Central Committee’s Fourth Plenum, suggesting a planned leadership transition. Analysts interpret this as President Xi consolidating power, removing trusted but potentially corrupt allies, and reshaping the military’s command structure to align with his political vision. The campaign also extends to other senior officials, including former political commissars and joint operations commanders, and reflects growing scrutiny of military personnel with long-standing ties to key political figures.
title: China expels two top generals from Communist Party in anti-corruption crackdown
